claim: The winter in London is cooler than in New York.

supporting.text: London has a maritime climate moderated by the Gulf Stream, resulting in milder winters compared to New York's continental climate.

attacks.text: London has a maritime climate moderated by the Gulf Stream, resulting in milder winters compared to New York's continental climate.
New York's winters are influenced by cold air masses from Canada, which can make them significantly colder than London's despite the maritime influence.
The Gulf Stream's warming effect on London is somewhat offset by its higher latitude compared to New York, leading to comparable winter temperatures in some years.
Historical temperature records show that New York frequently experiences lower winter temperatures than London, supporting the claim.
Urban heat island effects in New York can sometimes make its winters feel warmer than rural areas, but this does not negate the overall colder averages.

supporting.text: New York experiences colder winter temperatures due to its inland location and exposure to Arctic air masses from Canada.

attacks.text: New York experiences colder winter temperatures due to its inland location and exposure to Arctic air masses from Canada.
London's winters are moderated by the Gulf Stream, which brings warmer maritime air compared to New York's continental climate.
New York's urban heat island effect can sometimes offset the colder Arctic air influence, making its winters less extreme than expected.
The Gulf Stream's warming effect on London is diminishing due to climate change, reducing its moderating influence on winter temperatures.

supporting.text: Average winter temperatures in London are higher than those in New York, based on historical meteorological data.

attacks.text: Average winter temperatures in London are higher than those in New York, based on historical meteorological data.
New York experiences more extreme cold spells due to continental climate influences, which can make winters feel cooler despite similar average temperatures.
London's maritime climate moderates temperature extremes, leading to consistently milder winters compared to New York's more variable conditions.
Urban heat island effects in London may artificially inflate average winter temperatures compared to less urbanized areas of New York.
Meteorological data accounts for urban heat island effects by using standardized measurement locations, ensuring comparability between cities.

supporting.text: New York frequently receives heavier snowfall in winter compared to London, indicating colder conditions.

attacks.text: New York frequently receives heavier snowfall in winter compared to London, indicating colder conditions.
Snowfall is influenced by humidity and precipitation patterns, not just temperature, making it an unreliable indicator of coldness.
New York's proximity to the Atlantic Ocean results in higher humidity, which can lead to heavier snowfall even if temperatures are not significantly colder than London.
London's maritime climate moderates winter temperatures more than New York's continental climate, leading to cooler winters in New York despite snowfall differences.
Historical temperature data shows New York has lower average winter temperatures than London, supporting the claim that New York winters are cooler.

supporting.text: London's winter temperatures are less extreme due to the thermal inertia of the surrounding ocean, unlike New York's more variable continental climate.

attacks.text: London's winter temperatures are less extreme due to the thermal inertia of the surrounding ocean, unlike New York's more variable continental climate.
New York's proximity to the Atlantic Ocean also moderates its winter temperatures, reducing the difference in variability compared to London.
The Gulf Stream significantly warms Western Europe, including London, making its winters milder than New York's despite both being coastal cities.
Urban heat island effects in New York can make its winters warmer than surrounding rural areas, potentially narrowing the temperature gap with London.
London also experiences urban heat island effects, which may similarly elevate its winter temperatures, maintaining the relative difference.
